Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Collaborative Research: The Influence of Self-Avatars on Perception and Action in Virtual Worlds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to enable more effective design and use of virtual worlds. The pervasiveness of visually-oriented online and interactive digital media allows people to represent themselves increasingly through surrogates in virtual worlds. These digital personae are called "avatars," and when they closely represent the user, "self-avatars." Self-avatars enable forms of learning, interaction, and skill development that can increase a user's effectiveness in a virtual world. This project will explore how self-avatars play a significant role through three key components of perception and action: the relationship between action and the perception of space and objects, active acquisition of spatial memory, and the planning and execution of actions themselves.

This research will consider three properties of self-avatars themselves, each likely to have an effect across a broad range of situations: (1) the virtual perspective from which the avatar is seen, (2) the nature of the coupling between user size and motion and avatar size and motion, and (3) the naturalness of the interface system by which the user controls the avatar. The work builds on a growing body of knowledge about the role of body ownership in perceptual and cognitive tasks. This framework provides a theory in which to ground the research, a body of empirical knowledge about perception and action in the real world, and established methodologies that can be used for assessing the results of the research. The ability to utilize work from cognitive and perceptual science to solve a problem in computer graphics and user interaction is a major strength of the research.

Virtual environments are important in many domains, including architecture, education, medicine, simulation, training, and visualization. The core impact of this research is to enable self-avatars to enhance user experience in virtual environments, which are a major category of computer simulations. A broad impact of this project is that enhancing the user experience will lead to more capable applications of virtual environments in the aforementioned domains. This research will also have utility in entertainment systems, the dominant environments for avatars. It advances discovery and understanding while training students in cross-disciplinary research methods in an innovative intellectual environment. The interdisciplinary nature of the research and its consequent applications, together with the close integration of two research groups, will aid in bringing new students to computer science, beyond the students traditionally attracted to that field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The pervasiveness of visually-oriented online and interactive digital media forces us to represent ourselves increasingly through surrogates in virtual worlds. These digital personae are called avatars, and when they represent ourselves, self-avatars. Self-avatars enable forms of learning, interaction, and skill development that can increase a user's effectiveness in a virtual world. Cognitively, avatars help immerse the user within the simulation and provide a naturalistic way to interact with others in the simulation.  Perceptually, avatars help ground the user within the spatial layout of the simulation.  Despite the pervasiveness of avatars, we have little formal knowledge about how avatars affect the user experience in digital worlds.  This project generated essential discoveries about how self-avatars enable users to better perceive and act in virtual worlds, providing a critical and synergistic complement to existing work on the effect of avatars on social interactions and interpersonal space.


Intellectual Merit:  In multiple studies, we showed that the presence of self-avatars beneficially affects perception and action in virtual environments.  We showed that presence or manipulation of virtual body parts influences spatial decisions for object recognition, reaching  and gap-stepping.  A variety of factors were found to play a role in these effects. For example, motion-tracking of a self-avatar improved pointing to remembered targets. The presence of a self-avatar arm served as a quick and efficient means of counteracting spatial displacement in a visuo-motor recalibration task involving throwing. The displays on which the environments were viewed affected participants' affordance judgments or actions. The depiction of the self-avatar itself altered whether people were willing to accept the avatar as their own.  We published reviews on affordances and perspective taking  and on the role of the body and self-avatars in perceiving spatial layout in real and virtual environments. A final review on the use of affordances as a measure of perception and action with self avatars in virtual environments is soon to be submitted as well.


Broader Impacts: The feasibility of adding self avatars to virtual worlds has dramatically increased due to the proliferation of motion capture systems in gaming devices and consumer-grade head mounted displays.  The ability to effectively use these avatars in virtual environments is important for many applications, including training and rehabilitation where accurate perception of the environment is crucial.  This project also provided multidisciplinary training of students in a broad set of skills, including computer graphics and human perception and cognition.  Results have been published or are in submission to conferences and journals in computer science, psychology, and interdisciplinary outlets.
